content.question: The figure illustrates an experiment to determine the index of refraction of an unknown material. A laser beam in air is incident on a block of the unknown material, and the angles <math alttext="theta sub x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="theta sub y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>Y</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="theta sub z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>Z</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> can be measured. Which of the angles are needed to determine the index of refraction of the unknown material, and why are these angles needed?

choices.label: <math alttext="theta sub x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="theta sub y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>Y</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, because these are the angle of incidence and angle of refraction, respectively.

<math alttext="theta sub x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="theta sub z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>Z</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, because these are the angle of incidence and angle of refraction, respectively.

<math alttext="theta sub y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>Y</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="theta sub z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>Z</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, because both these angles are in the block.

<math alttext="theta sub x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="theta sub y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>Y</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="theta sub z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>Z</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, because all three angles are used in the equation relating the indices of refraction of the air and the unknown material.
